Sometimes we yield to the desire for incessant chauge3 sometimes we sink into inertness. These disappointed hopes prey ou the mind, a'nd we become envious of the success of others We suist and turn in hope that change may bring relief, we lose all power of forbearance, and end with disgust for life aud the world. The remedy for this is not, as Athenodorus advises, to re-enter the arena of public life, but to choose such occupatione in retirement as shall make our lives useful to others. We may serve the state by advising and directing the young, as well as by holding public offices. We are not to fiee from men and live only for ourselves. We remain citizeus; but of the world, not merely of a single state.
